text:
Removing all the Logger elements from server.xml seems to cause the server exit
on startup.
creator: bob@jadn.com
remm@apache.org
text:
I have a configuration like that, and it doesn't cause any problems. Log will go
to the sys.out.

creator: bob@jadn.com
text:
It may be a issue only on Unix boxes.  The system seems to "start to print out
an exception" logging something like "exception in Main " and it stops
abruptly.

Strangely, I found adding a Logger of type "SystemOutLogger" to the
Host section (which would logicly be an effective no-op as the default
should already be an instance of the system out logger) works just dandy.

If you choose to close this again, I wont reopen it.

Cheers,
-bob

creator: pier@betaversion.org
text:
Blatantly stupid suggestion, but you might use a FileLogger using /dev/null if you want to
save the performance impact caused by writing data on file (that's what I do, since I noticed
the same bug)...

Too bad that it won't save the overhead of preparing the messages to be logged, but you
can get a nice 10/15% of performance increase...

This looks like a VM crash, then. The rule is that if you can't point out to a
Tomcat bug which would cause the crash (since it is working perfectly well for
me on Windows, I don't see any bug), then the bug is invalid.

About the /dev/null thing: no logging occurs when running servlets, and I happen
to think that startup logging is important, so I don't see how this is useful.
creator: remm@apache.org
bob@jadn.com
text:
I suspect that Windows and Unix have slightly different implementations
of standard out.  The Unix version might have some rentrant issue - as
remmy points out - this is not a tomcat issue (directly.)  marked INVALID
